children.value: Matrices and vectors of the same size may be added elementwise.  Multiplication by a scalar is also defined elementwise. These operations obey the familiar laws of commutativity, associativity, and distributivity. The multiplication of two matrices, on the other hand, is less straightforward.
There are two ways for vectors to be multiplied together. If

Matrix multiplication is not commutative, i.e., the order of terms in a product matters to the result.

children.value: A matrix-matrix product is a horizontal concatenation of matrix-vector products involving the columns of the right-hand matrix. Equivalently, a matrix-matrix product is also a vertical concatenation of vector-matrix products involving the rows of the left-hand matrix.
The representations of matrix multiplication are interchangeable; whichever one is most convenient at any moment can be used.
